tossups.question: In a 2010 psychological experiment, a person dressed in this way stands in front of a curtain that changes color. A person was asked to dress in this manner in order to replicate a 1975 finding by Neisser and Becklen in which people shook hands instead of playing a hand-slapping game. In that later experiment, a person dressed in this manner appeared in a scenario that also used a tall woman holding an open umbrella. A person dressed in this way appeared during both the “easy” and “hard” counting tasks of an experiment designed by Christopher Chabris and Daniel Simons, in which a person dressed in this fashion tested inattention blindness by walking through a scene as participants were asked to count passes. For 10 points, seventy percent of subjects failed to see a person dressed in what mascot-like manner interrupting basketball players in a 1999 study?
tossups.answer: dressed in a gorilla suit [or wearing a gorilla costume, etc.; prompt on monkey or ape or other larger categories that a gorilla belongs to; prompt on answers such as dressed in black or in fur that are technically true of gorilla costumes but do not contain the word “gorilla”] <The above question is for the category Social Science Psychology and was written by Penelope Ashe>

tossups.question: In multivariate ANOVA, Wilks’ lambda statistic is equal to the ratio of two of these values. One of these values appears under the square root in the denominator of the density of a non-degenerate multivariate normal random variable. The positivity of a set of these values for certain nested objects is one side of Sylvester’s criterion. Types of these values known as principal minors appear in the sum used to compute this value via cofactor expansion. Each component of a vector is equal to the ratio of two of these values in a solution obtained by Cramer’s rule. This value for A minus lambda I is zero when lambda is an eigenvalue of the matrix A. For 10 points, give this value that is nonzero if and only if a matrix is invertible.
tossups.answer: determinant <The above question is for the category Science Math and was written by Tim Morrison>

tossups.question: An investigation into a faulty object of this type caused C. C. Young to endorse reports that did not jeopardize the funding for another of these objects in the Swing–Johnson Bill. The destruction of one of these things named for St. Francis in 1928 forced William Mulholland into premature retirement. At a dedication ceremony for one of these things in 1935, Harold Ickes (ICK-iss) sought to change the name of it as a partisan swipe at a political enemy. The construction of one of these edifices named for Michael O’Shaughnessy dramatically changed the Hetch Hetchy Valley in Yosemite National Park, but also created a reservoir servicing San Francisco. For 10 points, name these structures, one of which on the Colorado River is named for Herbert Hoover.
tossups.answer: dam [or St. Francis Dam; or Hoover Dam; or Boulder Dam; or O’Shaughnessy Dam] <The above question is for the category History American (1865-1945) and was written by Mike Cheyne>

tossups.question: A poem by this author describes “praising a forehead called the moon, singing desire into begin” and notes that “septembering arms of year extend less humbly wealth to foe and friend.” That poem describes a person moving “through theys of we, singing each new leaf out of each tree” and moving “through sames of am, through haves of give.” Another poem by this man describes its title location parenthetically as “(with up so floating many bells down)” and notes that “someones married their everyones.” In another poem, this author asks of “Mister Death,” “how do you like your blue-eyed boy?” For 10 points, name this poet of “Buffalo Bill’s,” “my father moved through dooms of love,” and “anyone lived in a pretty how town,” who styled his name in lowercase.
tossups.answer: E. E. Cummings [or Edward Estlin Cummings] <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by John Marvin>

tossups.question: This artist depicted a dog slumped on a path across from some orange and white flowers in the background of a painting in which his cousin Zoé (zo-AY) gazes into a Versailles-style box containing one of the title Orange Trees. In that painting, this artist’s brother Martial (mar-see-ALL) is reading in the shade, facing away from the viewer. This artist, who painted View of Rooftops (Effect of Snow), showed a man drying his back with a towel in Man at His Bath. In a scene by this artist, three shirtless men kneel on all fours next to a green bottle and use tools on a shiny floor. A dog walks past a man in white gazing over the edge of the title object in this painter’s Bridge of Europe. For 10 points, name this artist of The Floor Scrapers who painted people walking with umbrellas in Paris Street; Rainy Day.
tossups.answer: Gustave Caillebotte (kye-BUTT) <The above question is for the category Arts Painting and was written by John Marvin>

tossups.question: A controversial San Francisco obelisk claims that four members of the 5th Artillery were “murdered” in Sacramento by the participants of this event. During this event, a captain struck a protester in the head with his sabre in Livingston, Montana. Almost a week after this event ended, legislation to create Labor Day was pushed through Congress. John Altgeld called the response to this event “government by injunction,” believing that Richard Olney badly misinterpreted the Sherman Antitrust Act. This event was stopped when Grover Cleveland called in the army to stop a perceived threat to the country’s mail delivery system. For 10 points, name this 1894 labor uprising led by the ARU and Eugene V. Debs, which targeted a company that built railroad cars.
tossups.answer: Pullman Strike <The above question is for the category History American (1865-1945) and was written by Mike Cheyne>

tossups.question: The Angirasas (un-GHEE-ruh-suhs) do this action on behalf of Indra against the Panis (PUN-eez). After Kichaka’s death, the Trigartas perform this action against King Virata. That instance of this action occurs on the last day of the Pandavas’ exile, so Arjuna is free to reveal himself during the military offensive that occurs in response to this action. A hero engages in a series of single combats in an attempt to prevent an opposing force from performing this action, which culminates in that hero killing Ferdiad. That instance of this action was opposed by Cú Chulainn (koo-HULL-in) and carried out by an army led by Medb (mave). For 10 points, identify this type of action, one of which happens at Cooley, in which participants steal a certain animal.
tossups.answer: cattle raids [or any answer mentioning stealing or theft or rustling of cattle or cows; prompt on livestock theft] <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Conor Thompson>

tossups.question: While in an opium reverie, this story’s narrator sees four drops of ruby-colored liquid fall from nowhere into a goblet of wine. The narrator of this story compares the inscrutability of the title character’s eyes to a passage attributed to Joseph Glanvill, which also serves as the story’s epigraph. A character in this story recites a poem about a crowd of angels who watch a play about a writhing “blood-red thing” that kills everyone else. After the narrator’s second wife, Lady Rowena Trevanion, is struck by fever and dies, life repeatedly returns to and leaves her body until she transforms into the narrator’s first wife, this story’s raven-haired title character. For 10 points, name this Edgar Allan Poe short story that contains “The Conqueror Worm.”
tossups.answer: “Ligeia” (lye-JEE-uh) <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by Shan Kothari>

tossups.question: One of these compounds can undergo a [1,2]-sigmatropic rearrangement that was first observed in bicyclic terpenes; that type of reaction is a Wagner–Meerwein shift. Reacting norbornadienyl chloride with silver ions generated the first stable non-classical example of these species. The facile (FASS-ull) rearrangement of these species means that s-butyl chains cannot be attached to aromatic substrates via Friedel–Crafts alkylation. Beta-silicon atoms can help to stabilize these species by hyperconjugation. Unimolecular nucleophilic substitution reactions proceed via one of these species as an intermediate. Positive inductive effects cause tertiary examples of these species to be more stable than primary ones. For 10 points, name these species which contain a positive charge on a carbon atom.
tossups.answer: carbocations (carbo-CAT-ions) [prompt on cations] <The above question is for the category Science Chemistry and was written by Ewan MacAulay>

tossups.question: Noah Greenberg, W. H. Auden, and Chester Kallman collaborated on an anthology of songs originally accompanied by this instrument. Two musicians play just one of these instruments in the piece “My Lord Chamberlain, His Galliard” (GAL-yerd). The opening “falling tear” motif that descends from A to E is an example of the “word painting” in an ayre (air) for this instrument called “Lachrimae Pavan” (LACK-rim-ay pah-VON). Pieces for this instrument by composers like Vincenzo Galilei (veen-CHENT-so gah-lee-LAY) form the basis of Ottorino Respighi’s (ress-PEEG-ee’s) Ancient Airs and Dances. This instrument, which may have between 5 and 13 courses of strings, accompanies the songs “I saw my Lady weep” and “Flow my tears” by John Dowland. The guitarist Julian Bream helped revive this period instrument. For 10 points, name this fretted, plucked string instrument with a deep, pear-shaped body.
tossups.answer: lute <The above question is for the category Arts Music and was written by Shan Kothari>

tossups.question: Knocking down LRP1 or overexpressing RAGE in this structure promotes transport of a pathogenic 42-peptide protein across this structure into the parenchyma (puh-RANK-uh-muh). OX26 and 8D3 antibody conjugations target the transferrin receptor in this structure to facilitate receptor-mediated transcytosis. This structure is absent in the area postrema and other circumventricular organs such as the median eminence, which secretes into the hypophyseal portal system. This structure comprises non-fenestrated endothelial cells nurtured by astrocytic endfeet. Its tight junctions limit movement of large and hydrophilic molecules, making it difficult to treat infections in the CNS. For 10 points, name this protective semipermeable membrane formed by tight junctions in the cerebral vasculature that restricts passage of solutes into the brain.
tossups.answer: blood-brain barrier [or BBB; prompt on endothelial cells and endothelium before the former is read; prompt on blood vessels; prompt on brain before “postrema” is read] <The above question is for the category Science Biology and was written by Joelle Smart>

tossups.question: Simon bar Giora (gee-OR-ah) and Marcus Manlius died at a place named for this person. Immediately after the death of this person, boiling springs were created by Janus to protect the Forum. This woman was the daughter of the citadel commander Spurius and was serving as a Vestal Virgin during the invasion of Titus Tatius. This person sought gold bracelets from Sabine invaders but was instead crushed to death by shields after foolishly asking for “what you wear on your left arms.” At an outcropping named for this woman, traitors were thrown to their death from the Capitoline Hill. For 10 points, identify this mythical Roman traitor who names a “rock.”
tossups.answer: Tarpeia [or Tarpeian Rock] <The above question is for the category RMP Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Penelope Ashe>

tossups.question: al-Qazwini described a village where all the buildings were made of this material and local industry was staffed by Masufa slaves. This good is still traded at Berhale, where two-day caravan journeys bring it from the Danakil Depression. A route used to trade this good was marked by the erstwhile Tree of Ténéré. This good is traded on the Taghlamt and Azali routes. Around 1600, Taoudenni (TOW-den-nee) supplanted Taghaza as the main West African point of origin for this good, which is chopped into bricks and loaded onto camels. For 10 points, name this good that was traded southward in the Trans-Saharan Trade in exchange for gold, and was used to preserve food.
tossups.answer: salt <The above question is for the category History World and was written by Penelope Ashe>

tossups.question: John Cranko’s choreography for this ballet includes large corps de ballet sequences and a street fight that spills fruit across the stage. Its composer originally planned to have a sequence of divertissements immediately after the administration of poison, as well as a happy ending that changed the source material. Leonid Lavrovsky’s 1940 revision of this ballet is now the standard version. This ballet was composed over a summer at the Polenovo artists’ retreat. It was later excerpted into the Opus 75 suite Ten Pieces for Piano and several orchestral suites, one of which begins with music from its sections “The Prince Gives His Order” and “Dance of the Knights.” For 10 points, name this ballet by Sergei Prokofiev that is the source of the piece “Montagues and Capulets.”
tossups.answer: Romeo and Juliet [or Romeo i Dzhulyetta] <The above question is for the category Arts Ballet/Dance and was written by Penelope Ashe>

tossups.question: Outside of England, a small evangelical sect called “Countess of Huntingdon’s Connexion” only has a current notable presence in this country. An ethnic group in this country held celebrations in which they mocked European practices, called “Koonkings.” This country’s capital is home to “King’s Gate,” which bears an inscription that “any slave who passes through this gate is declared a free man.” This country’s capital was founded under its Cotton Tree. This country’s largest ethnic groups are the Mende (MEN-day) and Temne (TAME-neh). A small minority in this country are Krio people descended from Black Loyalists and other freedmen who returned here called the Nova Scotia Settlers. The Moa River forms part of this country’s border with Guinea and Liberia. For 10 points, name this west African country whose capital is Freetown.
tossups.answer: Republic of Sierra Leone [prompt on Salone] <The above question is for the category Geography World and was written by John Marvin>

tossups.question: This character rhetorically asks “will someone say that I disrespect old age if I intend to dance?” in a play in which he arrives at the house of Cadmus intending to head to a festival but is interrupted by Pentheus, who wants Dionysus dead despite this character’s protestations. This character says “you will lose a son of your own loins” to Creon before Haemon is found to have killed himself at the end of Antigone. At the start of another play, after a lengthy interrogation, this character tells the title character that “you yourself are the criminal you seek.” This character foresees that the murderer of Laius is the “son and husband of his own mother” in a play in which he is called upon by Oedipus due to his clairvoyant abilities. For 10 points, name this blind soothsayer from Greek myth, who was turned into a woman for seven years.
tossups.answer: Tiresias <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by Joseph Krol>

tossups.question: Operators corresponding to this quantity are specified in terms of creation and annihilation operators in the Holstein–Primakoff transformation. Networks named for this quantity were developed by Roger Penrose and are used to represent space in loop quantum gravity. The interaction of this quantity with an electromagnetic field is described by the Pauli equation, and the coupling of this quantity to orbital angular momentum is given by the Clebsch–Gordan coefficients. The Stern–Gerlach experiment used a magnetic field to separate particles based on their values for this quantity, which takes half-integer values for fermions. For 10 points, name this quantity, the intrinsic angular momentum of a particle.
tossups.answer: spin <The above question is for the category Science Physics and was written by Matt Mitchell>

tossups.question: The priest Horapollon is credited with producing an erroneous guide to carrying out this action. Antoine de Sacy and Johan Akerblad aided in the first successful modern attempt to perform this action, outlined in the Letter to Monsieur Dacier (dahss-YAY). The third volume of a book by Athanasius Kircher partially titled for Oedipus is a guide to doing this action, which he based in part on his knowledge of Coptic. Polymath Thomas Young made a major advance in attempts to do this by positing that the text inside a cartouche (kar-TOOSH) could be the name of an important person. For 10 points, name this task finally achieved by Jean-François Champollion via the Greek and Demotic inscriptions on the Rosetta Stone.
tossups.answer: deciphering hieroglyphics [or equivalents indicating understanding, reading, or translating hieroglyphics; prompt on deciphering, understanding, reading, or translating the Rosetta Stone until “Rosetta Stone” is read; prompt on translating Ancient Egyptian; prompt on translating ancient texts] <The above question is for the category History European 1400-1914 and was written by Daoud Jackson>

tossups.question: This man wrote about how “like a yellow silken scarf, the thick fog hangs along the quay (kee).” In a poem dedicated to Marcel Schwob, this writer enjoined a “lovely languorous” creature to “sing me all your memories” and described it as “half woman and half animal!” A voice whispers “That fellow’s got to swing” about a man who “walked amongst the Trial Men in a suit of shabby gray” in one of this man’s poems. This author of “Symphony in Yellow” and “The Sphinx” wrote a poem that claims “The coward does it with a kiss, the brave man with a sword!” in explaining that “Each man kills the thing he loves.” That poem describes his imprisonment for homosexuality at its title location. For 10 points, name this Irish author of “The Ballad of Reading Gaol (jail).”
tossups.answer: Oscar Wilde [Oscar Fingal O’Flahertie Wills Wilde] <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Shan Kothari>

tossups.question: Some scholars think the author of this book must not have been Jewish, since he seems to have misunderstood the Hebrew poetic parallelism in Zechariah. That misunderstanding led to Christ uniquely entering Jerusalem astride two donkeys in this gospel. This book uses the word “Israelites” up to the crucifixion, and afterwards switches to “Ioudaioi” (EYE-oo-DAY-uh-way). In a group of statements in this book known as the “antitheses” (an-TITH-uh-seez), which are prefaced with “you have heard it said,” Jesus tells the listeners to follow abstract principles even more rigorously than concrete rules, exemplifying his claim in this gospel that he has “not come to abolish the Law, but to fulfill it.” For 10 points, name this gospel that presents Jesus as the Jewish Messiah and contains the Sermon on the Mount.
tossups.answer: The Gospel According to Matthew [or Book of Matthew] <The above question is for the category RMP Christian/Bible Religion and was written by John Marvin>

tossups.question: The Cayley-Dickson construction can be used to generate a sequence of these things, each of which has twice the dimension of the last one. Clifford names a class of these things which generalize the complex numbers and their extensions. The “zero” type of these things contains elements such that the product of any two elements is zero. These things consist of a vector space endowed with a bilinear product. Any Lie group can be used to generate one of these things which is defined by using an operation called the Lie bracket. Lie and Boole name examples of, for 10 points, what mathematical structures which share their name with a branch of mathematics that has “linear” and “abstract” types?
tossups.answer: algebras [prompt on vector spaces until read] <The above question is for the category Science Math and was written by Conor Thompson> 2018 National All-Star Academic Tournament Round 5 – Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: In 1658, Robert Knox and his father of the same name set out on a trading voyage to Persia. For 10 points each:
answers: Dutch Empire [or the Netherlands; or Holland]
cannabis [or Cannabis indica; or marijuana] <The above question is for the category History World and was written by Daoud Jackson>
parts: Knox and his father were shipwrecked and forced to land in Sri Lanka where they were captured by forces loyal to this kingdom’s ruler Rajasinha II. This kingdom was previously subject to the Kotte kingdom.
Knox spent nineteen years in Kandy before escaping to Arippu, which was controlled by this European colonial empire. Jakarta was known as Batavia when it was ruled by this empire.
In addition to writing a best-selling account of his journey, Knox brought back the first described sample of this plant to Europe. An edible form of this plant is consumed as bhang in India.

bonuses.leadin: This city was founded by sociology professor Nat Mendelsohn, who bought 80,000 acres of desert in the hopes of outdoing Los Angeles. For 10 points each:
answers: Oak Ridge <The above question is for the category Geography US and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this failed planned city, which is mostly a sprawl of crumbling roads for unbuilt neighborhoods. It is the third largest municipality in its state by area despite a population of merely 14,000.

Unlike California City, this state’s planned city of Cape Coral grew to form a substantial metropolitan area with nearby Fort Myers. That city in this state has over 400 miles of canals, more than any other city on earth.
This planned city in Tennessee was built for the Manhattan Project. It is still home to a namesake national laboratory and the Y-12 security complex.

bonuses.leadin: After proposing a hypothesis for the origins of this region, J. Harlen Bretz was invited to debate with six “challenging elders” at the Geological Society of America meeting. For 10 points each:
answers: karst topography <The above question is for the category Science Earth Science and was written by Shan Kothari>
parts: Name this barren region in eastern Washington state that, according to Bretz and J. T. Pardee, was created by a series of cataclysmic glacial lake outburst floods following the last deglaciation, carving out basalt coulees and basins.

Bretz’s work on the Missoula Floods emphasized rare, catastrophic events, in contrast to this principle popularized by James Hutton and Charles Lyell, according to which the principles that operate today should be used to explain the past.

Bretz also did influential work on this kind of topography characterized by limestone or dolomite caves and sinkholes. Jovan Cvijić (YO-vahn ts’VEE-yeetch) studied the geomorphology of these regions in the Dinaric Alps.

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote the lines “I had read in books that art is not easy, but no one warned that the mind repeats in its ignorance the vision of others” in the poem “Dürer: Innsbruck, 1495.” For 10 points each:
answers: Australia <The above question is for the category Literature World and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this fictitious poet created by James McAuley and Harold Stewart to satirize and hoax modernist poetry, published in the magazine Angry Penguins.
The Ern Malley hoax inspired the book My Life as a Fake by this author of Oscar and Lucinda and The True History of the Kelly Gang.
Both Peter Carey and the creators of Ern Malley hailed from this country, whose “bush poets” such as Banjo Paterson wrote of life in the Outback.

bonuses.leadin: This physical theorem’s proof involves expanding a quadratic term whose cross-term, when integrated, disappears since it gives the body’s center of mass. For 10 points each:
answers: one-third [or 1/3] <The above question is for the category Science Physics and was written by Joseph Krol>
parts: Name this theorem in classical mechanics, usually expressed as I equals I-sub-c plus m-d-squared.

The parallel axis theorem aids the calculation of a quantity called the “moment of” this. This term describes the tendency of objects to keep moving at a constant velocity, for example in the context of Newton’s third law.

Suppose a uniform rod of mass m and length L rotates about (emphasize) one end. The parallel axis theorem can be used to show that the resulting moment of inertia is equal to this fraction multiplied by m-L-squared.

bonuses.leadin: At the insistence of Salvador Dalí, this painting was X-rayed, revealing that the artist had painted the ground in this painting over an earlier layer’s coffin. For 10 points each:
answers: the Barbizon school <The above question is for the category Arts Painting and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this painting that depicts two farmers with heads bowed between a pitchfork and a cart, reciting the title evening prayer.
The Angelus was painted by this French realist. In his painting The Gleaners, three peasant women gather leftover stalks of wheat.

Millet was part of this influential Romantic-Realist artistic school, named for a village near the Forest of Fontainebleau (fon-ten-BLO). Other members included Charles-François Daubigny (doh-been-YEE), Théodore Rousseau (tay-oh-DOR roo-SOH), and Jules Dupré (JOOL doo-PRAY).

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the relationship between Martin Luther King, Jr. and Malcolm X, for 10 points each.
answers: Elijah Muhammad [or Elijah Robert Poole; prompt on Muhammad] <The above question is for the category History American (1945-present) and was written by Mike Cheyne>
parts: King and Malcolm only met face-to-face briefly in Washington, D.C., during 1964 debates on this law that outlawed discrimination based on race. It was signed into law by Lyndon Johnson in July of that year.

In a 1965 interview with Alex Haley for this magazine, King said that he wished Malcolm would “talk less of violence.” In another interview for this magazine, Haley interviewed American Nazi leader George Lincoln Rockwell.

King sent a sympathetic telegram to Malcolm’s widow after Malcolm’s assassination, but did not comment on whether he believed that this leader of the Nation of Islam at the time of the killing was involved in the murder.

bonuses.leadin: This aria opens with the words “Thy hand, Belinda,” and features chromatic word painting on many of its key words. For 10 points each:
answers: “When I Am Laid In Earth” [accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, “Dido’s Lament”]
Benjamin Britten <The above question is for the category Arts Opera and was written by Joseph Krol>
parts: Name this aria from a seventeenth-century opera in which a character asks “Remember me, remember me, but ah! forget my fate.”
This character sings that aria in a Henry Purcell opera named for her and Aeneas. That opera is heavily based on the Aeneid and its stories of this queen of Carthage.

This twentieth-century composer extensively revised Dido and Aeneas, together with Imogen Holst, and is thus widely credited for popularising Purcell’s operas with the public. His own operas include Billy Budd and Gloriana.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about philosophers descended from the Akan (uh-KON) people of present-day Ghana, for 10 points each.
answers: Kwame Anthony Appiah (APP-ee-uh) [or Kwame Akroma-Ampim Kusi Anthony Appiah]
Gilbert Ryle <The above question is for the category RMP Philosophy and was written by Shan Kothari>
parts: Akan philosopher Anton Wilhelm Amo wrote a 1734 dissertation contesting this philosopher’s distinction between the res cogitans and res extensa, as described in Meditations on First Philosophy.
This British-born philosopher with an Asante father discussed the ethics of ethnic identity and cultural difference in Cosmopolitanism and In My Father’s House.
Kwasi Wiredu, who debated Akan notions of personhood with Kwame Gyekye (KWA-may JAY-chay), wrote his thesis at Oxford under this author of The Concept of Mind.

bonuses.leadin: A poem about a little girl in this situation begins with a stanza that ends “Know that, in a former time, Love! sweet Love! was thought a crime.” For 10 points each:
answers: Songs of Innocence and Songs of Experience
chimney-sweeper <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Shan Kothari>
parts: Name this situation that titles a William Blake poem about a girl named Lyca who is taken to a cave by a pair of lions. A boy in this metaphorical situation is burned at the stake for asking “Father, how can I love you or any of my brothers more?”
Blake’s poems about little boys and girls who are “lost” and “found” appear in this two-part collection, which also includes “The Little Black Boy” and “The Tyger.”
Songs of Innocence and Experience also includes two poems about boys who labor in this profession, including Tom Dacre, who dreams of being brought to heaven by an angel with a “bright key.”

bonuses.leadin: Infants are unable to synthesize this positively charged amino acid. For 10 points each:
answers: nitric oxide [or NO; do not accept “nitrous oxide”]
smooth muscle <The above question is for the category Science Biology and was written by Fred Morlan>
parts: Name this amino acid that is necessary to synthesize creatine. It contains a guanidino side chain and is found in high quantities alongside lysine in histones.
Arginine is a precursor for the synthesis of this compound, which was originally known as endothelium-derived relaxing factor or EDRF.
Nitric oxide promotes relaxation of this type of muscle, which allows it to play a role in vasodilation. Unlike skeletal and cardiac muscle, this kind of muscle is not under voluntary control.

bonuses.leadin: At a 1976 concert, a drunk Eric Clapton voiced support for this speech, declaring “Keep Britain White!” For 10 points each:
answers: Margaret Thatcher <The above question is for the category History European 1914-present and was written by Nitin Rao>
parts: Name this 1968 speech by Enoch Powell denouncing the Race Relations Bill and calling for an end to immigration. Some commentators credit the Conservative electoral victory in 1970 to this speech.

This Conservative Leader of the Opposition at the time sacked Enoch Powell from the Shadow Cabinet in response. During his government, Britain joined the European Community, and he imposed Direct Rule in Northern Ireland after Bloody Sunday.

Shortly after leaving office, this Prime Minister remarked that Powell “had made a valid argument, if in sometimes regrettable terms.” This “Iron Lady” defeated Heath to become Conservative Leader in 1975.

bonuses.leadin: The first of these things to be discovered was shown to exist by Émile Mathieu (ay-MEEL ma-TYUH) in 1861, while others are named for Zvonimir Janko (z’VOH-nee-meer YAHN-ko) and Bernd (burned) Fischer. For 10 points each:
answers: sporadic groups [prompt on finite simple groups]
commutative [or word forms such as commute] <The above question is for the category Science Math and was written by Joseph Krol>
parts: Name these things, of which there are 26. They are integral to a certain proof that spread over thousands of mathematical papers until Michael Aschbacher confirmed the proof to be complete in 2004.

A more typical set of finite simple groups, introduced by Galois (gal-WAH), are the alternating groups A-n, which are simple when n is greater than or equal to this integer. Galois’s work also paved the way for Abel’s proof that this number is the least for which a polynomial equation is unsolvable in radicals.

One easy case of classifying finite groups is for finite groups that are abelian, which means that multiplication within the group has this property. This property holds if a-times-b equals b-times-a for all elements in a set, so that the order of multiplication does not matter.

bonuses.leadin: In this story, the protagonist sits in a laundry-room for fifteen minutes, contemplating why he is willing to die in someone else’s place, before giving his interrogators what he thinks to be false intelligence about a gravedigger’s shack. For 10 points each:
answers: doctor [or physician] <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by Joseph Krol>
parts: Name this story in which Pablo Ibbieta escapes a death sentence after accidentally telling the truth that Ramon Gris (rah-moan GREE) is hiding in a cemetery.
“The Wall” is a short story by this French author and philosopher of Nausea and No Exit.

While the main characters of The Wall are imprisoned, a Belgian member of this profession comes to visit them, ineffectively trying to comfort them about their sentences. In another existentialist narrative, Bernard Rieux (ree-UH) is a member of this profession.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Supreme Court cases with something in common, for 10 points each.
answers: Larry Flynt [Larry Claxton Flynt Jr.] <The above question is for the category History American (1945-present) and was written by Mike Cheyne>
parts: Cases such as 1964’s New York Times Co. v. Sullivan involve issues of libel and defamation and thus relate to freedom of the press, a right outlined in this constitutional amendment.

In a 1974 case, the Court established protection against defamation claims when lawyer Elmer Gertz sued Robert Welch Incorporated, the legal name of this group, after it published an article insulting Gertz. This group was supposedly named after a missionary who was the “first casualty of the Cold War.”

In a 1988 case, the Court upheld the right to parody after evangelist Jerry Falwell sued this publisher of Hustler magazine for a satirical ad mocking Falwell. This free speech advocate was paralyzed after being shot by a white supremacist in 1978.

bonuses.leadin: This essay was written in response to Francis Fukuyama’s The End of History and the Last Man. For 10 points each:
answers: Bernard Lewis <The above question is for the category Social Science Social Criticism and was written by Nitin Rao>
parts: Name this essay that defines “torn countries” and identifies fault lines where conflict will occur. This essay argues that conflict between cultures will replace ideological struggle in the post-Cold War world.

This Harvard political scientist developed the Clash of Civilizations hypothesis and coined the term “third wave of democratization” in his similarly-named book analyzing democratic transition after the Carnation Revolution.

This British historian of the Middle East used the term “clash of civilizations” in his 1990 essay “The Roots of Muslim Rage.” He defended Orientalist scholarship in debates with Edward Said (sah-EED).

bonuses.leadin: This composer wrote a notturno in A-flat for solo piano which became the third part of his Liebesträume (LEE-biss-TROY-muh), or “Love’s Dreams.” For 10 points each:
answers: Les preludes [or Les preludes d’apres Lamartine] <The above question is for the category Arts Music and was written by Penelope Ashe>
parts: Name this piano virtuoso who depicted a Cossack warrior in Mazeppa and wrote the overture Tasso.
Mazeppa and Tasso are examples of this genre of single movement orchestral programmatic works, which Liszt invented.

This is Liszt’s third symphonic poem, although it was the first piece on which he applied that label. It uses music from The Four Elements and derives its program from an ode by Alphonse de Lamartine.

bonuses.leadin: Before becoming an unruly arhat, this servant explained sights to a prince, including a dead man and a sadhu, or wandering ascetic. For 10 points each:
answers: Surya <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Christian/Bible Religion and was written by Daoud Jackson>
parts: Name this charioteer who, with the help of the horse Kanthaka, guided Siddhartha Gautama around Kapilavastu (kah-pil-AH-vuss-too) to see the Four Sights.
This avatar of Vishnu is frequently depicted as a charioteer. He counsels Arjuna on the eve of battle in the Bhagavad Gita, part of the Mahabharata.
Bangkok is home to the Wat Arun, which is named for the charioteer of this Hindu sun god. He is often depicted in a celestial chariot pulled by seven horses.

bonuses.leadin: Anna imagines herself as a kindergarten teacher suffering from a syndrome called Acquired Toilet Disease in this woman’s play The Baltimore Waltz. For 10 points each:
answers: Yiddish <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by Danny Vopava>
parts: Name this American dramatist who described a girl sexually abused by her charismatic Uncle Peck in the 1998 play How I Learned to Drive.
Vogel was nominated for a Tony in 2017 for this play, which dramatizes the controversy generated by the American premiere of Sholem Asch’s play God of Vengeance.
God of Vengeance was originally written in this language. A rich theatrical tradition in this language was created by Ashkenazi (OSH-kuh-NAH-zee) Jews in Europe and America.

bonuses.leadin: Houyi travelled to this location to obtain the elixir of immortality. For 10 points each:
answers: Kunlun (k’wun-l’wun) [or Jade mountain; prompt on Chinese heaven or similar answers]
peach of immortality <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Paul Lee>
parts: Name this mythological mountain where the Queen Mother of the West resides. The rain god Yu Shi is also said to live on top of this mountain.
This half-snake, half-human Chinese hero married his sister Nüwa at the top of Kunlun Mountain. This man was the first to discover hunting and fishing, which he taught to his descendants.
This fruit grew in a garden in Kunlun Mountain and bestowed immortality upon those who ate it. It is served to all the immortals in a magnificent banquet every six thousand years.

bonuses.leadin: This man denied a sixth term to US Senator Thomas Hart Benton by pushing namesake pro-slavery resolutions through the state senate. For 10 points each:
answers: John Charles Frémont <The above question is for the category History American (pre-1865) and was written by Nitin Rao>
parts: Name this Democrat who was elected governor on a pro-Union ticket in 1860 but plotted to secede by seizing a US arsenal, leading to bloodshed with a force led by Nathaniel Lyon at Camp Jackson.
Jackson was governor of this border state but was forced into exile after the Confederate defeat at Pea Ridge. Franz Sigel led a Union volunteer regiment of German immigrants from this state.

This commander of the Department of the West was blamed for Lyon’s death and defeat at the Battle of Wilson’s Creek and was dismissed by Lincoln after emancipating the slaves of Missouri. This hero of the Mexican-American War was nicknamed the “Pathfinder.”
